column4: What I'm trying to do is change all instances, within a file, of ____.html to ____.php, where there is no .  or / immediately preceding the ____. So, I'd want misc.html to be misc.php, but I'd want www.site.com/misc.html to be unchanged.
This seems perfect for regular expressions, but I just can't seem to phrase it correctly.
Hey, I'm confused too. Thanks for trying. =P
Well, I can definitely understand if no one here knows much about sed, but could anyone suggest a better place to ask?
Hmm, interesting idea.
So yeah, maybe bash would be better. Didn't see it.
Oh, I see.
Well, the trouble isn't searching and replacing.
I want everything matching a pattern.
I want misc.html, llama.html, and foo.html to all become php files.
you want the rename utility
it's able to do complex renames like that.
Within a file?
ah
:s/.html/.php/g
in vim ;P
But I need exceptions.
I need it so that foo.html is changed but not http://bar.com/baz.html
hmm
These are webpages and I want external links to still w*ork.
that's a bit more complex a regexp
dunno how to make a replace like that using the vim style.
it is possible though.
